For posterity (and for me to always remember):
What I forgot is: Expression.resolvedType can typically have one of 3 states: (1) a good type binding (2) a problem type binding (3) null
The typical interpretation (though I'm afraid we're not 100% consistent): (2) can mean: the problem has not yet been reported, let caller do so; can also mean: problem is not extreme, caller may use the closestMatch to avoid secondary errors (3) can mean: not initialized; can also mean: severe problem that got already reported.
don't we all love the null value? ;-P
